repnme.cdata!:
Liberia - First and Second Petroleum
            Exploration Promotion Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The First and Second Petroleum
            Exploration Promotion Projects in Liberia was successful.
            The relationship with the Borrower was usually very good.
            The International Development Association (IDA) did not
            perceive in time, however, the progressive deterioration of
            the Atlantic Resources Limited (ARL)'s services, and as
            a result did not intensify its control of the
            consultant's performance. Furthermore, IDA was not
            vigilant regarding conformity to the Bank's procurement
            guidelines. The Implementation of the project would have
            been improved by hiring a resident independent part-time
            exploration advisor, who could have supervised the
            consultant's selection, technical work, and invoicing,
            by closer IDA supervision. Which could have avoided the
            inadequate implementation of several components of the
            projects, and unduly high costs for the Borrower. If and
            when the World Bank resumes lending to Liberia, it will be
            urgent to assist in privatizing the Liberian Petroleum
            Refining Company (L.P.R.C), and improving the management of
            the petroleum products supply and storage, in order to stop
            the Government's financial deficiency.

docna.cdata!:
Liberia - Petroleum Exploration Promotion
            Project : Loan 1907 - Loan Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Liberia - Petroleum Exploration
            Promotion Project : Loan 1907 - Loan Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The Petroleum Exploration Project aims
            at attracting oil companies to take oil exploration permits
            in Liberia, where no exploration has taken place since 1972.
            Studies conducted recently have concluded that
            Liberia's petroleum potential remains to be
            established; both seismic studies and the analysis of the
            samples of the four wells that were drilled indicate the
            possibility of finding hydrocarbons. The project consists
            of: (i) a new seismic survey of Liberia's offshore, the
            computer processing, interpretation and integration of the
            new data; (ii) consulting services for the promotion,
            auction and negotiation of new exploration permits; (iii)
            technical assistance for energy planning; and (iv) technical
            assistance to the Bureau of Hydrocarbon of the Ministry of
            Lands and Mines. The project does not face any major risks.
            The financial exposure of the Government is likely to be
            greatly diminished through the sale of a report on
            Liberia's offshore prospects to oil companies. There is
            already a significant industry interest in the report.
